justification: “the model incorporates an emotional intensity scale ranging from 1 to 5 … The intensity of each force, whether conative or inhibitory, is thus quantified along this scale.”
“Techniques such as self-report scales … can be used to estimate the relative magnitude of these affective forces.”
“Techniques such as … physiological monitoring (e.g., heart rate variability, skin conductance) … can be used to estimate the relative magnitude of these affective forces.”
Same sentence notes “physiological monitoring (e.g., heart rate variability, skin conductance)” as tools to gauge the size of the forces.
The list of tools also includes “behavioral indices” for estimating the magnitude of conative and inhibitory forces.
“The parameter k can be empirically calibrated through … physiological measurements, such as heart rate variability.”
The same calibration passage adds “or hormonal assays” as physiological measures tied to k.
Under ‘Psychometric Calibration’ the authors state: “Using moral value scales … we can calibrate k to reflect real-world sensitivity to moral decision-making.”
The same section proposes “decision-making surveys” as another psychometric route for estimating k.
“Neuroimaging tools such as EEG … can help identify the brain regions and neural signatures involved in moral evaluation.”
The same sentence pairs EEG with “fMRI” for tracking neural signatures of moral evaluation.
The neuroimaging sentence also lists “conflict processing” among the functions that EEG can illuminate.
Likewise, fMRI is noted for identifying neural signatures involved in conflict processing.
The authors mention EEG in relation to “decision thresholds” in moral tasks.
In the same clause, fMRI is presented as a tool for probing neural signatures behind decision thresholds.
